# Draft:Slavery in precolonial sub-Saharan Africa

Domestic or patriarchal slavery in pre-colonial Sub-Saharan Africa refers to systems in which enslaved individuals were integrated into households, kinship networks, or community structures, often participating in family life and sometimes achieving social mobility. This form of slavery was distinct from chattel or plantation slavery.
Regional overview
Kingdom of Kongo
Estimated domestic/patriarchal share: ~75%
Captives were incorporated into households, working as domestic servants or laborers, with some potential for social advancement.
Mali Empire
Estimated domestic/patriarchal share: ~75%
Domestic and community service roles predominated. Soninke domestic slaves lived with families and could not be sold.
Swahili Coast (East Africa)
Estimated domestic/patriarchal share: ~80%
Early slavery was mostly domestic; large-scale plantations developed later.
Forms of slavery
Most enslaved individuals served in domestic or household roles. Other roles included military service, palace labor, and limited agricultural work. Integration into households often allowed for familial relationships and some social mobility.
